Title: Prove that a cyclic group with only one generator can have at most 2 elements
Content: Prove that a cyclic group that has only one generator has at most $2$ elements. I want to know if my proof would be valid: Suppose $G$ is a cyclic group and $g$ is its only generator. Let $|G|=n$ where $n>2$ , then we know that $\gcd(n,n-1)=1$ . This implies that $g^{n-1}$ is a generator of $G$ . We have a contradiction, since $g$ is the only generator of $G$ (and $n > 2$ leads to $n-1 \neq 1$ ). Thus $|G|\leq 2$ . I tried to use the fact that generating elements of a group are coprime to the order of the group, thanks.
AcceptedAnswer: Perhaps easier: if $g$ generates $G$ , then so does $g^{-1}$ . The hypothesis then implies that $g=g^{-1}$ , so $g^2=1$ . Done (either $g=1$ or not, in which case respectively the order of $G$ is $1$ or $2$ ).
